philosophyOptions.label: Descriptive questions/hypotheses aim to describe aspects of the world without assigning meaning to the finding. No requirements.
Mechanistic questions ask how components of a system give rise to outcomes at a higher level. They require causal insights and generally require perturbations.

Normative questions ask how a given outcome at a high level can be seen as being useful in the niche of the animal (e.g., "a memory of location allows you to find home"). They require information about the niche.
Evalution questions ask how a given outcome evolved by requiring distinct species or fossil records.
Representation questions ask how activities in brains relate to stimuli or behaviors (e.g. how does reward change the activity of a neuron) and require the manipulation of stimuli or behaviors.
Developmental questions ask how change during an organism's lifetime gives rise to outcomes and require observing that change.
Combination questions ask how above questions relate, e.g. about the mechanism of development.
